posts.title: Pro Tips for Recording and Mixing Dialogue
posts.author: Kris Janowski
posts.summary: Whether itâ€™s a podcast, video, or voiceover, clean, professional dialogue makes all the difference. Here are my best practices.
posts.content:
## The Secret to Pro-Level Dialogue Audio

Whether youâ€™re recording a podcast, an interview, a YouTube video, or professional voiceover, **dialogue quality can make or break the listenerâ€™s experience**.

Iâ€™ve worked with dialogue and vocal production for years, and while the tools matter, itâ€™s the techniques that truly elevate spoken-word audio.

Here are my go-to tips for recording, mixing, and mastering dialogue to a professional standard.

## Recording Tips: Get It Right at the Source

The biggest mistake I see? People think they can â€˜fix it in the mixâ€™. **No plugin can rescue a bad recording.**

### 1. Choose the Right Microphone

* **Dynamic mics** (like the Shure SM7B) are great for untreated rooms.
* **Condenser mics** (like Audio-Technica AT2020) capture more detail, but require a quiet, treated space.

### 2. Room Matters More Than Gear

* Record in the quietest space possible.
* Use curtains, duvets, or foam to reduce reflections.
* Avoid rooms with hard walls and floors that bounce sound.

### 3. Control the Proximity Effect

* Keep the speaker **3â€“6 inches** from the mic.
* Use a pop filter to prevent plosives (p and b sounds).
* Donâ€™t let speakers move around while talking â€” consistency is key.

### 4. Record Clean and Conservatively

* Set recording levels to peak at **\-6 dBFS**.
* Always record in **24-bit WAV** if possible.

## Mixing Tips: Clarity and Warmth

Once youâ€™ve captured a clean recording, itâ€™s time to polish.

### 1. Clean Up Background Noise

* Use Logic Proâ€™s **Noise Gate** gently to reduce low-level hum.
* For tougher noise, **manual editing** or dedicated tools like iZotope RX (if available) can help.

### 2. EQ for Intelligibility

* **High-pass filter** around 80â€“100 Hz to remove rumble.
* Cut any harsh frequencies between 2â€“4 kHz **carefully**.
* Add slight boost around 1.5 kHz or 3 kHz if the voice sounds dull.

Logicâ€™s **Channel EQ** is all you need here. Itâ€™s clean and surgical.

### 3. Compression for Consistency

* Use **Logic Proâ€™s Compressor** in Vintage Opto or Studio VCA mode.
* Aim for gentle compression â€” **2:1 or 3:1 ratio**, 3â€“5 dB of gain reduction.
* Fast attack (20â€“30 ms), medium release (50â€“100 ms) is usually a good starting point.

### 4. De-essing

* Logicâ€™s **De-Esser 2** can tame sharp â€˜sâ€™ and â€˜shâ€™ sounds.
* Donâ€™t overdo it â€” preserve natural brightness.

## Mastering Tips: Broadcast-Ready Sound

Even simple mastering can make dialogue sound professional and consistent across devices.

### 1. Loudness Normalization

* Target **\-16 LUFS** for podcasts/video.
* For YouTube, Spotify, and Apple standards, stay between -16 and -14 LUFS.

### 2. Final EQ Polish

* Logicâ€™s **Linear Phase EQ** can add gentle air (boost around 10 kHz) without introducing phase shift.

### 3. Limiting

* Use Logicâ€™s **Adaptive Limiter**.
* Set the ceiling to **\-1 dBFS** and apply subtle limiting to prevent clipping.

## Bonus Tip: Always Listen on Multiple Devices

Before finalizing, test your mix on:

* Studio monitors
* Headphones (studio and consumer)
* Smartphone speakers

What sounds balanced in the studio might be bass-heavy or tinny elsewhere.

## Final Thoughts

**Clean dialogue is a skill and an art.**

Itâ€™s not about using every plugin or chasing loudness wars. Itâ€™s about delivering clarity, warmth, and emotion that connects with the listener.

If you need help getting your dialogue or voice recordings to a professional standard â€” or want full mixing/mastering services for your podcast or video content â€” feel free to reach out via my contact page[](https://krisjanowski.co.uk/contact).

Your words deserve to be heard *at their best*.

posts.title: The Role of Environment and Gear in Pro Audio Production
posts.author: Kris Janowski
posts.summary: Why the room, the mic, and the treatment are as important as the performance itself â€” and how to master your space.
posts.content:
## The Overlooked Factor: Your Environment

When people think of great sound, they think of great mics, plugins, or instruments. **But the room you record in can make or break the final result.**

Early in my career, I spent years upgrading equipment without realizing that my untreated room was working against me. Once I addressed my environment, everything changed.

## Why Environment Matters

### Reflections and Reverb

Every room reflects sound waves. In an untreated space, reflections bounce back into the microphone, creating:

* **Comb filtering** (weird phasing effects)
* **Boxy or muddy tone**
* **Unwanted reverb** that blurs the clarity of your recording

### The Myth of 'Fixing It in the Mix'

You *canâ€™t EQ out room reflections or phase problems*. Plugins like Logic Proâ€™s Channel EQ or Space Designer can shape a sound â€” but they canâ€™t remove the physical effects of a bad room.

## Recording Equipment: Tools That Complement the Space

### Microphones

Your mic choice should match both the *source* and the *environment*.

* **Dynamic mics** (Shure SM7B, Electro-Voice RE20) reject more room noise â€” great for untreated or noisy rooms.
* **Condenser mics** (Audio-Technica AT4050, Rode NT1-A) capture more detail â€” but only sound their best in treated spaces.

### Interfaces and Preamps

While a high-quality interface (like the Universal Audio Volt series or Focusrite Scarlett range) can improve conversion and preamp clarity, **it canâ€™t compensate for poor mic technique or room acoustics**.

## The Science of Reverb: Friend and Foe

**Reverb adds realism and emotion** when used correctly â€” but itâ€™s also the most common source of problems.

### Natural Reverb

* *Too much*: Makes recordings sound distant or muddy.
* *Too little*: Can make vocals or instruments sound unnatural or sterile.

### Artificial Reverb (Mixing Stage)

In Logic Pro, tools like **Space Designer** or **Chromaverb** can create lush, controlled ambiences. But these should be **added deliberately in the mix**, not baked into the recording.

## Best Practices for Mastering Your Recording Space

### 1. Treat Your Room

* Use bass traps and broadband absorbers in corners and on reflection points.
* If treatment isnâ€™t an option, record near soft furnishings or hang heavy blankets.

### 2. Mic Placement

* Keep the mic away from walls or corners.
* Experiment with distance and angle â€” small changes can have big effects.

### 3. Use Temporary Fixes When Needed

* For mobile setups, portable vocal booths or reflection filters can help.

## Final Word

**Your environment is the invisible member of your production team.**

You can have the best mic, the best plugins, and world-class mastering tools. But if the room fights against you, every mix will be a struggle.

Understanding the interaction between space, mic, and performance is the foundation of pro-quality audio.

If you want help evaluating your space, choosing the right gear, or want me to handle mixing/mastering for your tracks or dialogue, head to my contact page[](https://krisjanowski.co.uk/contact). Letâ€™s make sure your sound is working *with* you â€” not against you.

posts.title: My Favourite Plugins for Modern Mixing
posts.author: Kris Janowski
posts.summary: A look at some of the tools I use every day to shape pro-level mixes.
posts.content:
## Tools That Shape the Sound

Ask any mixing engineer and theyâ€™ll tell you â€” tools donâ€™t make the mixer. But the right tools, used with experience and intention, can absolutely unlock creativity and precision.

Over the years, my workflow has evolved, but certain plugins have become trusted allies in helping me shape polished, professional mixes. I work entirely in **Logic Pro**, and while third-party plugins have their place, Logicâ€™s stock tools are often more powerful than many people realize.

Hereâ€™s a breakdown of the plugins I reach for in almost every project:

### 1. **Channel EQ (Logic Pro)**

Donâ€™t underestimate Logicâ€™s built-in Channel EQ. Itâ€™s clean, transparent, and incredibly efficient. Whether Iâ€™m sculpting out low-end mud, controlling harshness, or enhancing presence, this EQ does the job without adding unwanted colour.

For more surgical cuts or complex frequency work, I sometimes layer **FabFilter Pro-Q 3** â€” still my favourite for detailed EQ shaping when absolute precision is required.

### 2. **Compressor (Logic Pro)**

Logicâ€™s Compressor is criminally underrated. I often switch between its different models (Platinum Digital, Vintage FET, Studio VCA, etc.) depending on the source. The SSL-style **Vintage VCA** model is particularly good at gluing buses together in a subtle, musical way.

When I want a more classic â€˜mix glueâ€™ vibe, I occasionally reach for **Waves SSL G-Master Buss Compressor**, though Logicâ€™s built-in options often hold their own.

### 3. **Vintage EQ Collection (Logic Pro)**

Logicâ€™s Vintage EQs (Vintage Console EQ, Vintage Graphic EQ, and Vintage Tube EQ) beautifully emulate classic hardware tone-shaping. They add character and warmth without overdoing it. I often use the **Vintage Tube EQ** to add subtle air or weight to vocals and overheads.

### 4. **Space Designer & ChromaVerb (Logic Pro)**

Reverb can either place a track perfectly in the mix or drown it in mud. **Space Designer** remains my go-to for natural spaces, while **ChromaVerb** shines when I want something more modern or experimental.

For more lush, creative reverb textures, **Valhalla VintageVerb** remains a favourite â€” especially when crafting ambient depth or cinematic layers.

### 5. **Tape Delay (Logic Pro)**

Simple, effective, and great-sounding. Logicâ€™s Tape Delay has been a part of my sound design since day one. Whether itâ€™s a slapback vocal effect or tempo-synced delays to add movement, this plugin is a constant companion.

### 6ï¸âƒ£ **Exciter & Saturation Tools (Logic Pro)**

A little harmonic enhancement can go a long way. Logicâ€™s **Exciter** plugin lets me add subtle (or not-so-subtle) brightness and energy to elements that need to cut through the mix. 

For grittier saturation or character, **Soundtoys Decapitator** is still my go-to â€” it adds warmth, weight, or even controlled distortion when needed.

## Itâ€™s Not Just About the Tools

I canâ€™t stress this enough: **plugins are only as good as the hands using them**.

Mixing isnâ€™t about stacking every plugin you own on every channel. Itâ€™s about making intentional choices that serve the song. Sometimes, less is more. Sometimes, creative rule-breaking is what makes a track come alive.

My approach is always to:

**1. Listen deeply first.**\
**2. Understand the artistâ€™s vision.**\
**3. Use tools to enhance â€” not overpower â€” the emotion of the music.**

## Why This Matters in 2025

The modern listenerâ€™s expectations are high. Whether they realize it or not, theyâ€™re used to hearing polished productions with balanced frequencies, controlled dynamics, and immersive spatial depth.

For independent artists, the gap between DIY and pro-level sound can feel intimidating. My job as a mix and mastering engineer is to bridge that gap.

Whether Iâ€™m using Logicâ€™s native tools or carefully chosen third-party plugins, my goal remains the same:

**To take your creative vision and make it shine with clarity, power, and emotional impact.**

## Final Thoughts

At the end of the day, no plugin can replace taste, experience, or the ability to serve the music. But the right tools can certainly make the journey smoother and the results more inspiring.

posts.title: 5 Common Mixing Mistakes (And How to Avoid Them)
posts.author: Kris Janowski

posts.content:
## Avoid These Pitfalls for a Better Mix

Every mixing engineer, from beginner to veteran, has fallen into at least a few of these traps. Early in my journey, I made every mistake on this list. The good news? Each one offers a learning opportunity.

Letâ€™s break them down:

### 1. **Mixing Too Loud**

Itâ€™s tempting to crank up the monitors or headphones. Loud playback makes everything sound more exciting. But itâ€™s also deceptive.

ðŸ”Š **Why itâ€™s a problem:**
- Louder levels can trick your ears into thinking a mix is better balanced than it really is.
- Youâ€™re more likely to miss subtle imbalances or overdo compression/EQ.

ðŸ”Š **My tip:**
- **Mix at moderate levels**. Your ears wonâ€™t fatigue as quickly, and your balance decisions will be more accurate.
- Frequently **check your mix at low volumes** (this is how many listeners will hear it anyway).

### 2. **Overprocessing**

I get it â€” plugins are fun. With so many powerful tools available (especially inside Logic Pro), itâ€™s easy to throw everything at a mix.

ðŸ”§ **Why itâ€™s a problem:**
- Stacking too many EQs, compressors, and effects can strip away the life of a performance.
- Instead of clarity, you get mud or harshness.

ðŸ”§ **My tip:**
- Always ask yourself: *Whatâ€™s the purpose of this plugin?* If you canâ€™t answer clearly, it probably doesnâ€™t need to be there.
- **Less is often more**.

### 3. **Neglecting Reference Tracks**

Mixing in isolation can be dangerous. Without context, itâ€™s easy to lose perspective.

ðŸŽ§ **Why itâ€™s a problem:**
- You might unintentionally create a mix thatâ€™s too bright, too dark, or too narrow compared to industry standards.

ðŸŽ§ **My tip:**
- Pick **2 to 3 professionally mixed tracks** in the same genre as your project.
- Regularly **A/B compare** to stay grounded.

### 4. **Ignoring Phase Issues**

Phase problems can turn a potentially great mix into a hollow, weak mess â€” especially with multi-mic setups (like drum kits or layered guitars).

ðŸŒ€ **Why itâ€™s a problem:**
- Phase cancellation can suck out low-end power and stereo width.

ðŸŒ€ **My tip:**
- **Check phase alignment early**, especially when combining multiple mics or layering similar sounds.
- Logic Proâ€™s **Direction Mixer** and **Gain plugin with phase invert** can be your best friends here.

### 5. **Forgetting the Listenerâ€™s Experience**

In the pursuit of technical perfection, itâ€™s easy to forget what really matters: *how the music makes the listener feel*.

ðŸ‘‚ **Why itâ€™s a problem:**
- You might end up chasing a perfect-looking frequency curve or stereo spread that sacrifices emotional impact.

ðŸ‘‚ **My tip:**
- Regularly step back and listen like a fan, not an engineer.
- Ask: *Does this mix convey the feeling the artist intended?*

## Final Thoughts

Mixing is as much about psychology as it is about sound. Itâ€™s a balance between knowing the technical principles and trusting your instincts.

## From Bedroom Producer to Professional Engineer

I didnâ€™t even know what 'mixing' or 'mastering' truly meant â€” I just knew that some songs sounded huge, polished, and full of life, while others felt flat or crowded. I was determined to understand why.

## The Science Behind the Sound

As I grew older, I realized that technical knowledge would be as important as creativity. Thatâ€™s why, alongside my growing portfolio of music projects, I chose to study **Neuroscience** at university. Some might find that an odd choice for a musician, but to me, it made perfect sense.

Understanding how the human brain perceives sound has given me an edge in production. I gained insights into spatial perception, frequency masking, and even the psychology of musical expectation â€” all of which inform my mixing and mastering decisions to this day.

After earning my BSc, I pursued a **PGCE in Secondary Chemistry**. Teaching taught me something else critical to music production: how to communicate complex ideas clearly. Whether working with artists, producers, or labels, the ability to explain my creative and technical choices has been invaluable.

## Finding My True Path: Production

Throughout this time, I never stopped creating. I released solo projects, collaborated with other artists, and dove into every aspect of audio production. But I always felt that the finishing stages â€” mixing and mastering â€” were where I could truly elevate a song from good to unforgettable.
